head.supplied: Govnt House ¶ 8 April 56 ¶ My dear Sir William ¶ ¶ I am truly glad to find that I have satisfied you in my selection of Mueller to accompany the North Australian Expedition — I was very well pleased ...

div.p: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, Archives, DC/74/52.

I am truly glad to find that I have satisfied you in my selection of Mueller to accompany the North Australian Expedition — I was very well pleased with what I saw of him [judging] of course […. this] from the very fleeting transient view I had of him and from his correspondence with me. He was recommended to me by Professor Harvey —
I think that the Expedition will be successful, that is that the men will return safe – […] successful in [… …]they must be if they get back that is they will discover much that is unknown [as yet]

I confess that I do not participate in [start p 2] Sturts views of the advantages which will be delivered from this country should it prove as fertile as the valley of the Nile — by no possible process can it ever become a channel of communication from [these Colonies] to the North & thus to India &c an odd thousand miles or so of [hard …] is not so easily got over. — [the sphere] of our knowledge however will be extended – the Botany, Zoology – Geology of [those …] will be ascertained – and certain doubtful geographical questions may be put to rest —

I had all the members of the expedition before me previous of their embarkation and gave them a lecture on the necessity of subordination & [start p. 3] […] of […] – I was afraid that the scientific members might not be disposed to [yield] [themselves] to Mr Gregory, and that being gathered from the East & West, [North] & [South] they might not harmonize with each other — I have heard of their arrival at the mouth of the River [the]navigation is not […] and they ran [a Coral]Reef & had to wait for a Spring Tide to float them off. the [account] of [this …] in the vicinity of the mouth of the river is […] considering they have lost some horses, but were to push up the country about the beginning of October – the hot season will by then have […]. However we will hope for the best. I have asked to be permitted to send a small vessel to look [p. 4 start] after them in case of any accident & hope this will be acceded to - […] the report of Mr Gregory at the Col. Office- I forwarded it by the last mail. —

I am attempting to establish a philosophical society here and am about to experiment on the strength & the physical properties of the woods we sent[home to the Paris exhibition – should you wish forduplicate specimens of them & when the Expns are made, give you the results with the […]
